questions.question: Where is your pain located?
How did the pain begin?
How long have you been experiencing the pain?
What currently aggravates your pain?
What makes your pain better?
Do you experience any numbness or tingling sensation in your legs or feet?

rule_out: lumbar disc herniation or cauda equina syndrome

questions.question: Have you experienced any weakness in your legs?
Have you had any recent trauma or injury to your lower back?
Have you had any previous episodes of low-back pain?
Are you experiencing any bowel or bladder dysfunction, such as difficulty or loss of control in urination or defecation?
Have you had any recent fever, chills, or other signs of infection?

rule_out: ankylosing spondylitis or bone tumours and infection

questions.question: Have you had any recent unintended weight loss?

tests.name: Lasegue’s Test (Straight-Leg Raise)
tests.procedure: Examiner raises legs of patient up so that hip flexion is achieved while knee is extended. Test is positive if patient feels pain along the course of the sciatic nerve and below the knee when hip is between 30 - 70 degrees of flexion.

tests.name: Bragard Test
tests.procedure: This is a modification of the SLR and dorsiflexion is applied at the end of the SLR. This reduces the angle where the test is positive.

questions.question: Do you experience paraesthesia or abnormal sensation in the affected leg?
Does your job or daily tasks involve adopting physically awkward positions?
Do you experience muscle weakness in the affected leg?
Is the pain worsened with flexion of the spine, twisting, bending and/or coughing?
Do you experience pain when elevating the heel or tip-toeing?
Have you had a previous surgical procedure and/or injection recently?

tests.name: Lasegue’s Test (Straight-Leg Raise)
tests.procedure: Examiner raises legs of patient up so that hip flexion is achieved while knee is extended. Test is positive if patient feels pain along the course of the sciatic nerve and below the knee when hip is between 30 - 70 degrees of flexion.

tests.name: Bragard Test
tests.procedure: This is a modification of the SLR and dorsiflexion is applied at the end of the SLR. This reduces the angle where the test is positive.

tests.name: Bowstring Test (Popliteal Compression Test/ Tibial Nerve Stretch Sign)
tests.procedure: This can be done while patient is lying in supine or sitting position. The examiner flexes the knee and applies pressure on the popliteal fossa evoking sciatica.

tests.name: Clinical Observation
tests.procedure: Check if knee jerk reflex is present

tests.name: Clinical Observation
tests.procedure: Check if ankle jerk reflex is present

questions.question: Is the pain you feel aggravated by prolonged walking, standing and lumbar extension?
Do you experience pain radiating to the buttocks, thigh and legs after walking a certain distance?
Is the numbness you feel over the entire leg?
Is the pain you feel relieved by forward flexion (bending forward)?
Do you find walking upstairs easier than walking downstairs?
Do you experience any form of erectile dysfunction?
Is tenderness present at the lumbar, paraspinal or gluteal region?

tests.name: Bicycle Stress Test
tests.procedure: Record the amount of time the patient spends on a cycle ergometer while in a neutral lumbar position and slumped position. If patient spends more time in the slumped position, a lumbar spinal stenosis is indicated.

tests.name: Two-stage Treadmill Test
tests.procedure: The patient walks on a flat treadmill and the amount of time spent is recorded and compared with the amount of time while the treadmill is inclined such that patient walks in flexion.

tests.name: The Lumbar Extension-Loading Test
tests.procedure: The examiner ensures that the lumbar region is in moderate extension (10-30 deg) while standing and patient lies supine. Check if there are changes in the symptoms that the patient feels.

tests.name: Clinical Observation
tests.procedure: Check if a wide-based gait is present

tests.name: Clinical Observation
tests.procedure: Check if Trendenlenburg’s sign is present

tests.name: Clinical Observation
tests.procedure: Check if Achilles tendon reflex is diminished

questions.question: Was the pain onset immediately after a heavy lifting?
Does your job or daily task involve long sitting with lateral bending and rotation?
Do your symptoms feel better when lying supine with your hips and knees flexed?
Do you experience pain radiating to buttock and leg?
If yes, does this pain get worse with sitting and relieved with standing?

tests.name: Lasegue’s Test (Straight-Leg Raise)
tests.procedure: Examiner raises legs of patient up so that hip flexion is achieved while knee is extended. Test is positive if patient feels pain along the course of the sciatic nerve and below the knee when hip is between 30 - 70 degrees of flexion.

tests.name: Bragard Test
tests.procedure: This is a modification of the SLR and dorsiflexion is applied at the end of the SLR. This reduces the angle where the test is positive.

tests.name: Bowstring Test (Popliteal Compression Test/ Tibial Nerve Stretch Sign)
tests.procedure: This can be done while patient is lying in supine or sitting position. The examiner flexes the knee and applies pressure on the popliteal fossa evoking sciatica.

tests.name: Femoral Nerve Stretch Test (Wasserman sign)
tests.procedure: Patient is in prone position, knee is flexed and hip is extended. Reproduction of pain in anterior thigh is positive.

tests.name: Kernig Test
tests.procedure: Patient’s neck is flexed, hip flexed and the leg is extended. Pain is reproduced in this position.

tests.name: Milgram Test
tests.procedure: pain is reproduced on straight leg elevation for 30 seconds.

tests.name: Clinical Observation
tests.procedure: Check for tenderness in the paraspinal musculature

tests.name: Clinical Observation
tests.procedure: Check for spasms in the paraspinal musculature

tests.name: Clinical Observation
tests.procedure: Check for decreased reflexes: patellar and ankle jerk

tests.name: Clinical Observation
tests.procedure: Check for trendenenburg’s sign

questions.question: Do you experience pain radiating to both legs?
Do you have a previous history of tumors or trauma to lower back?
Do you experience reduced sensation around your perineal (around genitals) region?
Do you experience reduced sensation in the region of your inner thighs (groin)?
Have you just undergone a lumbar spinal surgery?
Do you find it difficult to initiate urination or experience urinary retention (inability to empty the bladder completely)?
Do you experience bowel incontinence and/or constipation?
Do you experience reduced sexual sensations?

tests.name: Clinical Observation
tests.procedure: Check for babinski sign and clonus to rule out upper motor neuron involvement

entry_criteria.description: Age (common in teens and early adults)

questions.question: Do you have a family history of ankylosing spondylitis or any other autoimmune diseases?
Is the pain worse at night and early morning?
Does exercise and physical activity relieve the pain?
Do you experience pain and stiffness in your hips and/or buttocks?
Do exercises and physical activity reduce the associated stiffness?
Do you experience pain and stiffness in your neck or upper back?
Do you experience fatigue, difficulty sleeping and/or general feelings of unwellness?
Do you experience chest pain or discomfort, especially when you take deep breaths?
Have you experienced any symptoms such as red, scaly patches on your skin that may be accompanied by itching or discomfort (psoriasis)?
Have you experienced changes in your posture, such as stooping or hunching forward (question mark sign)?
Have you had any instances of eye inflammation or redness, or increased sensitivity to light (uveitis)?

tests.name: Lateral lumbar flexion (Finger tip to Floor Test)

The patient stands with heel touching wall and feet wide apart, and back against the wall. Then the examiner measures the distance from middle finger to the floor. Then patient bends to side (lateral flexion)
tests.procedure: . The distance between the middle finger and the floor is measured again. This measurement is done for both sides.

tests.name: Modified Schrober’s test
tests.procedure: Examiner marks both posterior superior iliac spine, and a horizontal line is drawn between both marks. A second line is marked 5cm below the first line, and a third line is marked 10 cm above the first line. Patient is then instructed to flex forward as if attempting to touch their toes.An increase of less than 5cm, shows decreased lumbar spine range of motion, and ankylosing spondylitis.

tests.name: Chest expansion- Normal chest expansion is ≥ 5 cm.
Occiput to wall distance- Normally is 0
Tragus to wall distance- Normally is < 15cm
